content: The fire incident data reveals a fluctuating trend over the years, with a notable increase in 2023. The higher frequency of incidents during April and July implies heightened fire risks during these months. These numbers highlight the urgency for post-fire mitigation strategies in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains area near Las Vegas, NM. It is crucial to implement effective measures to protect the water supply and reduce future wildfire dangers. Here are the connections between the literature search results and your concerns:

1. The study by Furman (1978) focuses on regionalizing climatic characteristics affecting wildfire ignition potential. Understanding the moisture content of fuels in mountainous regions with varied elevations and aspects is crucial for effective fire control strategies. Implementing mitigation measures based on these climatic factors can enhance post-fire recovery efforts in the Sangre de Cristo Mountains near Las Vegas, NM.

2. Campbell and Shinneman (2017) explore the role of wildfire in modulating climate-induced forest redistribution in mountain landscapes. This research highlights how wildfire can influence tree species distribution under changing climates. Insights from this study can guide adaptive strategies to manage post-fire landscapes and enhance ecological resilience in the face of climatic variations.

3. Fernandes and Botelho (2003) provide a comprehensive review of prescribed burning effectiveness in reducing fire hazards. The study emphasizes the importance of prescribed burning in mitigating wildfire risks by reducing fire intensity, size, and damage. These findings offer valuable insights for implementing prescribed burning as a proactive measure to mitigate future wildfire threats and safeguard water supply in high-risk areas.

References:
- Furman, R. (1978). Wildfire zones on a mountain ridge. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1467-8306.1978.tb01183.x
- Campbell, J., & Shinneman, D. (2017). Potential influence of wildfire in modulating climate-induced forest redistribution. https://doi.org/10.1186/s13717-017-0073-9
- Fernandes, P., & Botelho, H. (2003). Review of prescribed burning effectiveness in fire hazard reduction. https://doi.org/10.1071/wf02042
